section.title: Web service configuration
section.para: The web service configuration is stored in one database table 'gi_webservice_config'. Each row represents one configured web service with all it's configuration data in one field, stored as a single line in YAML format.

row.entry: a name to identify the web service

it's used as an other identifier for the web service
to enable or disable the web service

section.para: Another table 'gi_webservice_config_history' stores the older configuration versions. So when an update is made, the row in 'gi_webservice_config' is updated, and the old value added as a new row in 'gi_webservice_config_history' table.

section.title: Adding a new web service configuration
section.para: We can add a new web service configuration using one of the available tools for this action, one in command line, and other one in the web interface, for both you need to have your complete configuration in a YAML file, with the structure and content showed below, it will be use as the base for execute your web service.

section.title: By command line
section.para: You can use the command line tool to perform some action for webservices such: read,write (add or update), list and delete. Example: Creating a new webservice configuration:

Also you can use 'otrs.WebserviceConfig.pl' with next options:
To read a stored config -a read -i webservice_id
To create a new config -a write -n webservice_name -f /path/to/yaml/file
To update a config -a write -i webservice_id -f /path/to/yaml/file
To list available config -a list
To delete a config -a delete -i webservice_id
